high_relevance.description: Learning theory focusing on how newcomers become integrated into communities of practice through gradually increasing participation
high_relevance.relevance_to_rqs: Directly addresses RQ1 by explaining the trajectory from novice to core participation and identifies barriers to this progression
high_relevance.relevance_to_model: Could model different participation levels (peripheral, inbound, insider) and transitions between them; adds nuance to 'Skill up' and 'Promotion Rate' flows
high_relevance.phd_contribution: Operationalizes LPP in OSS context with quantitative SD modeling, identifying specific thresholds and barriers in the participation trajectory

high_relevance.description: Explains how newcomers learn the values, abilities, and behaviors needed to assume organizational roles
high_relevance.relevance_to_rqs: Addresses RQ1 (socialization process) and RQ2 (interventions to smooth the process)
high_relevance.relevance_to_model: Could model socialization tactics (collective vs individual, formal vs informal) and their impact on skill acquisition and promotion rates
high_relevance.phd_contribution: Applies organizational socialization to distributed, voluntary OSS communities, identifying unique socialization mechanisms

high_relevance.description: Organization's ability to recognize, assimilate, and apply new knowledge
high_relevance.relevance_to_rqs: Addresses RQ2 (interventions for knowledge transfer) and RQ3 (preventing failures from knowledge gaps)
high_relevance.relevance_to_model: Could model how prior knowledge and learning mechanisms affect the community's ability to absorb and retain expertise
high_relevance.phd_contribution: Extends absorptive capacity to OSS communities as knowledge-intensive systems, modeling knowledge retention dynamics

adjacent_opportunities.description: Focuses on individuals who connect their organization to external environments and transfer information across boundaries
adjacent_opportunities.why_adjacent: Shifts focus from linear progression to network positions and information brokerage
adjacent_opportunities.novel_angle: Views core developers as boundary spanners between community and external knowledge, explaining their critical role in knowledge transfer
adjacent_opportunities.phd_contribution: Identifies boundary-spanning roles in OSS and their impact on community resilience and knowledge flow

adjacent_opportunities.description: Psychological theory linking perceived competence to motivation and sustained engagement
adjacent_opportunities.why_adjacent: Brings individual psychological factors into a primarily social-structural model
adjacent_opportunities.novel_angle: Explains turnover and promotion dynamics through individual motivation and self-efficacy rather than just social factors
adjacent_opportunities.phd_contribution: Integrates psychological motivation with community participation models in OSS contexts

adjacent_opportunities.description: Examines how organizations become similar through coercive, mimetic, and normative isomorphism
adjacent_opportunities.why_adjacent: Focuses on macro-level institutional pressures rather than micro-level learning processes
adjacent_opportunities.novel_angle: Explains how OSS communities develop similar career paths and practices through institutional pressures
adjacent_opportunities.phd_contribution: Applies institutional theory to voluntary technical communities, identifying isomorphic pressures in OSS

cross_domain_inspiration.parallel: OSS communities as ecosystems with pioneer species, climax communities, and succession patterns
cross_domain_inspiration.transfer_potential: Models community maturation, species (role) replacement, and resilience to disturbances
cross_domain_inspiration.rationale: Provides powerful metaphors for understanding community evolution and vulnerability patterns

cross_domain_inspiration.parallel: High-reliability organizations managing distributed expertise and preventing system failures
cross_domain_inspiration.transfer_potential: Error prevention strategies, communication protocols, and distributed decision-making in high-stakes environments
cross_domain_inspiration.rationale: Offers proven interventions for preventing system failures in knowledge-intensive distributed teams

cross_domain_inspiration.parallel: Structured progression from novice to master through guided practice and gradual responsibility increase
cross_domain_inspiration.transfer_potential: Formalized mentorship structures, competency benchmarks, and gradual responsibility transfer
cross_domain_inspiration.rationale: Provides historical perspective on expertise development that could inform modern OSS mentorship

phd_strategy.rationale: LPP provides the core theoretical foundation for the career progression; Absorptive Capacity addresses knowledge transfer and system vulnerability concerns; Boundary Spanning adds network perspective to complement the linear progression model
phd_strategy.integration_strategy: Use LPP as primary framework for RQ1, integrate Absorptive Capacity to address RQ2 and RQ3 knowledge aspects, and employ Boundary Spanning to explain network positions and information flow patterns
phd_strategy.expected_impact: Creates a multi-level theoretical framework explaining individual progression (LPP), community knowledge dynamics (Absorptive Capacity), and network structure effects (Boundary Spanning) on OSS sustainability
